channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Prominent Egyptian Activists Detained for Protesting Under New Law
item.description: Video posted online showed police officers aiming a water cannon directly at protesters, including several prominent activists, who were chanting against Egyptian military rule outside the upper house of Parliament in Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: A New University Offers Liberal Arts as Higher Education Alternative
item.description: The founders of Ashoka University aspire to establish an alternative to what they say is an educational paradigm that overly emphasizes technical capabilities.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: An artist's impression of Ashoka University, currently under construction in Kundli, Haryana.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Group Skeptical of Talks
item.description: The planned international conference on ending Syria’s civil war encountered its first obstacles, a day after it was announced in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Scotland Unveils ‘Landmark Document’ on Independence from Britain
item.description: The proposal, 670 pages long, is part of an effort by Scottish authorities to answer many questions about the implications of independence.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.S. Flies B-52s Into China’s Expanded Air Defense Zone
item.description: Two long-range American bombers have conducted what Pentagon officials described as a routine training mission through international air space recently claimed by China.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: 30 Haitians Dead After Boat Capsizes off Bahamas
item.description: About 100 people were also stranded after their 40-foot vessel ran aground and tipped over, the United States Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: United States Coast Guard, via Reuters
item.media:description: Approximately 100 Haitians awaited rescue on a capsized boat near Staniel Cay, Bahamas on Tuesday.

item.title: Health Group Retracts Claim That ‘Self-Inflicted’ H.I.V. Is Common in Greece
item.description: The World Health Organization blamed an editing error for a widely reported claim that many Greeks infect themselves to get benefit payments.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM

item.title: A Tale of Love, Taxes and Bribery Entrances Brazil
item.description: How did an $82,000-a-year tax inspector amass a fortune said to be about $8 million? Prosecutors offer an explanation.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: In Major Document, Pope Francis Presents His Vision
item.description: In the pope’s first significant piece of written work, Francis called on Christians to create a more compassionate church that champions the poor.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: New Clues May Change Buddha’s Date of Birth
item.description: At a temple in Nepal that contains a pillar documenting a homage at the Buddha’s birthplace, researchers determined that lower structures were erected as early as the sixth century B.C.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: Archaeologists have uncovered a series of ancient temples within the Maya Devi Temple in Nepal.

item.title: Obama’s Visiting Security Adviser Tells Karzai to Sign Agreement
item.description: Susan E. Rice told President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to sign a security agreement or potentially face the complete pullout of American troops by the end of 2014, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: At War Blog: The Man Behind the MRAP Moves On
item.description: Ashton B. Carter, the departing deputy secretary of defense, played a central role in the initiative to rush MRAPs to Afghanistan for the troop surge.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marines Corps MRAPs in Afghanistan, ready to be sent back to the United States as part of the withdrawal process in 2012.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 26
item.description: The Taj Mahal hotel in Mumbai, Maharashtra, was one of the sites of the deadly terrorist attacks of Nov. 26, 2008.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A laborer erecting a stage in front of the Taj Mahal hotel, one of the sites of the Nov. 26, 2008 attacks, in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

item.title: France Adds Troops in Central African Republic
item.description: The French defense minister, announcing that France would increase its force to 1,000 troops, said that the African country “is in collapse.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Pakistan Breaks Ground on Nuclear Power Plant Project With China
item.description: The project is expected to be a major step in meeting Pakistan’s growing energy crisis.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Bangkok Protests Spur Concerns About Thai Stability
item.description: In a country that has become less governable amid a bitter political rivalry, protesters on Tuesday disrupted operations at several government ministries.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Opposition protesters waved national flags during a rally at the Interior Ministry in Bangkok on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Parents Receive Life Sentences in Murders of Daughter and Domestic Worker
item.description: A court in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, handed down life sentences to Rajesh and Nupur Talwar for the murders of their teenage daughter and domestic worker.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Journalists waiting outside a court in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh, on Monday where the proceedings of the trial of Rajesh and Nupur Talwar was taking place.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Send ‘Jade Rabbit’ Rover to the Moon
item.description: The mission was described as one of the most difficult to date for China’s space program.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Visitors photographed a model of the Jade Rabbit lunar rover at an industrial fair in Shanghai.

item.title: Protests Continue as Ukraine Leader Defends Stance on Europe
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovich again defended his decision to suspend preparations for accords with Europe that were to be signed this week.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Qualcomm Faces Antitrust Investigation in China
item.description: The timing of the inquiry has led some to question whether the Chinese government may be trying to gain leverage for its upcoming royalty negotiations with the American company.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Paul E. Jacobs, Qualcomm's chief executive.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Prabhat Jauhari, C.E.O. of Mumbai Private Security Firm
item.description: Mr. Jauhari spoke about how people’s perception about security has changed in the five years since the terror attacks in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Prabhat Jauhari, chief executive officer of Tops Air Rescue and Topsline Life Response Services.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Typhoon Haiyan Through the Lens of China’s 2008 Quake
item.description: The Philippine typhoon took far fewer lives than the 2008 Sichuan earthquake in China, but the magnitude of the disaster in some ways seemed greater in the typhoon.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Hundreds of bodies of Typhoon Haiyan victims were laid out along a road outside Tacloban, in the Philippines, awaiting mass burial.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Popping the Question, Tuhao-Style
item.description: Expensive marriage proposals in China have been criticized online using a newly coined word.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:description: Xu Pengjie posted shoes to show his Weibo followers that he was serious about giving out 1,000 pairs during his marriage proposal.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Dominican Republic: Fearful Haitians Deported or Voluntarily Flee
item.description: At least 350 Haitians and people of Haitian descent have either been expelled from the Dominican Republic or left on their own accord in recent days after two Dominicans were killed, said Lolo Sterne, coordinator for Haiti’s Office of Migration, on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Wanted Exile’s Attempt to Surrender Is Rejected
item.description: The second most-wanted student leader from the 1989 Tiananmen Square pro-democracy protests was turned back from Hong Kong on Monday in his latest attempt to surrender to Chinese authorities and return home.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
